paper_abstract: It is proved that the set of scattered substrings of a language recognized by an n-state DFA requires a DFA with at least 2(n/2-2) states (the known upper bound is 2(n)), with witness languages given over an exponentially growing alphabet. For a 3-letter alphabet, scattered substrings are shown to require at least 2(root 2n+30-6) states. A similar state complexity function for scattered superstrings is determined to be exactly 2(n-2) + 1 for an alphabet of at least n-2 letters, and strictly less for any smaller alphabet. For a 3-letter alphabet, the state complexity of scattered superstrings is at least 1/54(root n/2)n(-3/4).
paper_title: On the State Complexity of Scattered Substrings and Superstrings
